Welcome to Arcade!

Arcade is a website where you can play, and publish simple Sprite games with a high level programming language. Perfect for beginners.
Hello world!
Hello world!
Hello world!
Pauses code for the specified amount of seconds.
Syntax
WAIT (seconds)
Example 1 — Delay between logs

LOG "Start"
WAIT 1
LOG "One second later"
This logs "Start", waits one second, then logs "One second later".
Example 2 — Ticking loop

LOOP
  LOG "tick"
  WAIT 0.5
END LOOP
This produces a repeating tick message every 0.5 seconds using a LOOP.
Spawns a sprite at the given position. Coordinates and expressions are supported.
Syntax
SPAWN (sprite) AT (x),(y)
Example 1 — Basic spawn

SPAWN sprite1 AT 10,10
LOG "spawned sprite1 at 10,10"
Spawns sprite1 at coordinates (10,10) and logs a confirmation.
Example 2 — Spawn using variables and expressions

STORE 20 AS posX
SPAWN sprite2 AT posX,sprite1.y+5
Stores 20 in posX then spawns sprite2 at (posX, sprite1.y + 5), showing expression usage.
Example 3 — Spawn from an event

ON KEY 's'
  SPAWN sprite3 AT sprite1.x+30,sprite1.y
END KEY
Spawns sprite3 next to sprite1 when the 's' key is pressed.
Removes a spawned sprite so it is no longer drawn or touched.
Syntax
DESPAWN (sprite)
Example 1 — Manual despawn

DESPAWN sprite1
LOG "sprite1 removed"
Removes sprite1 and logs that it was removed.
Example 2 — Despawn on touch

ON TOUCH spriteA WITH spriteB
  DESPAWN spriteB
  LOG "Removed the second sprite on touch"
END TOUCH
When spriteA touches spriteB, spriteB is removed and a message is logged.
Moves a sprite to the specified position. Expressions and variables are supported for coordinates.
Syntax
MOVE (sprite) TO (x),(y)
Example 1 — Absolute move

MOVE sprite1 TO 100,100
LOG "moved sprite1 to 100,100"
Moves sprite1 directly to (100,100) and logs the action.
Example 2 — Move continuously in a loop

LOOP
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+2,sprite1.y
  WAIT 0.05
END LOOP
Moves sprite1 2 units to the right every 0.05 seconds creating smooth motion.
Example 3 — Using stored position

STORE 50 AS targetX
MOVE sprite2 TO targetX,10
Stores a target x coordinate and moves sprite2 to (targetX, 10).
Scales a sprite by the specified multiplier (positive number).
Syntax
SCALE (sprite) TO (multiplier)
Example 1 — Reduce size

SCALE sprite1 TO 0.5
LOG "sprite1 half size"
Scales sprite1 to half its original size and logs the change.
Example 2 — Scale on key press

ON KEY 'z'
  SCALE sprite1 TO 2
END KEY
When 'z' is pressed, sprite1 is scaled to twice its size.
Example 3 — Alternating scale in a loop

LOOP
  SCALE sprite2 TO 1
  WAIT 2
  SCALE sprite2 TO 1.5
  WAIT 2
END LOOP
Alternates sprite2 size between 1 and 1.5 every 2 seconds.
Applies a color tint to a sprite using a hex color (#rrggbb or #rgb).
Syntax
TINT (sprite) TO (hex)
Example 1 — Make red

TINT sprite1 TO ff0000
LOG "sprite1 is red"
Tints sprite1 red and logs the action.
Example 2 — Change tint over time

TINT sprite2 TO #00ff00
WAIT 1
TINT sprite2 TO #0000ff
Tints sprite2 green, waits 1 second, then tints it blue.
Example 3 — Tint on touch

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  TINT sprite1 TO #ffff00
END TOUCH
When sprite1 touches sprite2, sprite1 is tinted yellow.
Rotates a sprite to the specified degrees (can be negative).
Syntax
ROTATE (sprite) TO (degrees)
Example 1 — Rotate to 90

ROTATE sprite1 TO 90
LOG "sprite1 rotated to 90deg"
Rotates sprite1 to 90 degrees and logs the change.
Example 2 — Rotate continuously

LOOP
  ROTATE sprite1 TO sprite1.rotation+45
  WAIT 0.2
END LOOP
Adds 45 degrees to sprite1 rotation every 0.2 seconds to spin it.
Hides a sprite visually but keeps it in the scene (you can still move or touch it).
Syntax
HIDE (sprite)
Example 1 — Hide then show

HIDE sprite1
WAIT 1
SHOW sprite1
Hides sprite1 for one second, then shows it again.
Example 2 — Hide on key press

ON KEY 'h'
  HIDE sprite2
END KEY
Hides sprite2 when the 'h' key is pressed.
Shows a sprite that was previously hidden.
Syntax
SHOW (sprite)
Example 1 — Show after delay

HIDE sprite1
WAIT 2
SHOW sprite1
LOG "sprite1 visible again"
Hides sprite1, waits two seconds, then shows sprite1 and logs the event.

Stores a computed value in a variable for later use. Variable names must be a single word and cannot be 'sprite<number>'.

You can also generate random values with this by using `value#value`.
Syntax
STORE (value) AS (varname)
Example 1 — Score counter

STORE 0 AS score
STORE score+1 AS score
LOG score
Initializes score to 0, increments it and logs the new value.
Example 2 — Save spawn position

SPAWN sprite1 AT 10,10
STORE sprite1.x AS posX
MOVE sprite2 TO posX,50
Stores sprite1.x in posX and moves sprite2 to use that stored coordinate.
Example 3 — Store in an event

ON KEY 'r'
  STORE 100 AS lives
END KEY
When 'r' is pressed, sets lives to 100 for later use.
Example 4 — Random Position

SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,0
ON KEY 'r'
  STORE 0#100 AS randomX
  STORE 0#100 AS randomY
  MOVE sprite1 TO randomX,randomY
END KEY
When 'r' is pressed, the sprite moves to a random position between 0-100 x and y.
Logs a string or expression to the console. Strings support ${...} interpolation using current variables and sprite properties.
Syntax
LOG (string or expression)
Example 1 — Log values

LOG 10
LOG score
LOG sprite1.x
Logs a number, a variable and a sprite property.
Example 2 — Interpolated message

STORE 5 AS score
LOG "CURRENT SCORE: ${score}"
Stores score then logs a human-friendly message using interpolation.
Example 3 — Log from a touch event

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  LOG "Touched: ${sprite1.x}, ${sprite2.x}"
END TOUCH
Logs the x positions of two sprites when they touch.
This sets the text under the game window. Strings support ${...} interpolation using current variables and sprite properties.
https://hc-cdn.hel1.your-objectstorage.com/s/v3/be9d916a48e5918f833b7004ce7a3c184cc0d715_screenshot_from_2025-09-29_10-35-50.png
Syntax
TEXT (string or expression)
Example 1 — Log values

TEXT 10
TEXT score
TEXT sprite1.x
Sets the text to a number, a variable and a sprite property.
Example 2 — Interpolated message

STORE 5 AS score
TEXT "CURRENT SCORE: ${score}"
Stores score then sets the text to a human-friendly message using interpolation.
Awards experience points (XP) to the user in the specified size. This can trigger a level-up if enough XP is accumulated. XP sizes are SMALL, MEDIUM, or LARGE.
Syntax
GIVE XP (size)
Example 1 — Award small XP

GIVE XP SMALL
LOG "Awarded small XP"
Awards a small amount of XP and logs a confirmation.
Example 2 — XP on touch event

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  GIVE XP MEDIUM
  LOG "Collected medium XP!"
END TOUCH
Awards medium XP when sprite1 touches sprite2 and logs the event.
Example 3 — XP in a scoring loop

LOOP
  STORE score+1 AS score
  IF score IS 10
    GIVE XP LARGE
    LOG "Level up bonus!"
    STOP LOOP
  END IF
  WAIT 0.5
END LOOP
Increments score in a loop, awards large XP and stops when score reaches 10.
Repeats the commands inside the block until the loop is stopped or the program ends. Loops can be nested. Use WAIT inside loops to control timing. STOP LOOP stops the nearest running loop.
Syntax

LOOP
   ...commands...
END LOOP

Use 'STOP LOOP' inside a nested block to break the loop when a condition is met.
Example 1 — Continuous movement

LOOP
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+1,sprite1.y
  WAIT 0.05
END LOOP
Moves sprite1 continuously to the right in small steps creating smooth motion.
Example 2 — Loop with stop condition

ON KEY 's'
  STORE 0 AS score
  LOOP
    STORE score+1 AS score
    LOG "Score: ${score}"
    IF score IS 10
      STOP LOOP
    END IF
    WAIT 0.2
  END LOOP
  LOG "LOOP DONE"
END KEY
Starts a loop when 's' is pressed, increments score until it reaches 10 then stops and logs 'LOOP DONE'.
Runs the commands inside the block only when a condition is true. Both left and right sides are full expressions (numbers, strings, sprite properties, variables). Condition uses strict equality.
Syntax

IF (left expression) IS (right expression)
  ...commands...
END IF
Notes
IF blocks are awaited when executed, so WAIT inside an IF will pause that IF's block. IF supports nesting and works well with STORE, LOOP and events.
Example 1 — Simple numeric check

STORE 5 AS score
IF score IS 5
  LOG "SCORE IS FIVE"
END IF
Checks if score equals 5 and logs a message if true.
Example 2 — React to a sprite property

SPAWN sprite1 AT 10,20
IF sprite1.x IS 10
  LOG "sprite1 is at x=10"
  MOVE sprite1 TO 20,20
END IF
If sprite1.x equals 10, logs a message and moves sprite1 to (20,20).
Example 3 — Expression comparison

STORE 3 AS lives
IF lives+2 IS 5
  LOG "You have 5 lives total (including bonus)"
END IF
Evaluates an expression on the left and compares it to the right — useful for computed conditions.
Example 4 — String comparison & interpolation

STORE "player" AS who
IF who IS "player"
  LOG "Hello, ${who}!"
END IF
Checks a string variable and uses interpolation inside the logged message.
Example 5 — Nested IF

STORE 10 AS score
IF score IS 10
  LOG "Score is 10"
  IF score IS 10
    LOG "Nested: still 10"
  END IF
END IF
Demonstrates nested IF blocks — inner IF will run because the outer condition is true.

Runs the code inside the block when a key on the keyboard is pressed. Use single-character keys wrapped in quotes (e.g. 'w'). You can start loops, store variables, and spawn/move sprites in the handler.
Syntax

ON KEY '(key)'
  ...commands...
END KEY
Example 1 — Move on key

ON KEY 'w'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y-5
END KEY
Moves sprite1 up when the 'w' key is pressed.
Example 2 — Start a scoring loop

ON KEY 's'
  STORE 0 AS score
  LOOP
    STORE score+1 AS score
    LOG "Score: ${score}"
    IF score IS 10
      STOP LOOP
    END IF
    WAIT 0.2
  END LOOP
  LOG "LOOP DONE"
END KEY
Begins a loop when 's' is pressed that increments score until it reaches 10.
Example 3 — Spawn & tint on key

ON KEY 'p'
  SPAWN sprite2 AT sprite1.x+30,sprite1.y
  TINT sprite2 TO #00ff00
END KEY
Spawns sprite2 next to sprite1 and tints it green when 'p' is pressed.
Runs the code inside the block when one sprite's rectangle intersects another. Use this to react to collisions: update score, despawn, change tint, etc.
Syntax

ON TOUCH (spritename) WITH (spritename)
  ...commands...
END TOUCH
Example 1 — Simple touch log

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  LOG "Sprites touched!"
END TOUCH
Logs a message when sprite1 and sprite2 touch.
Example 2 — Score on touch

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  STORE score+1 AS score
  LOG "Score is now ${score}"
  DESPAWN sprite2
END TOUCH
Increments the score, logs it, and removes sprite2 when the two sprites collide.
Example 3 — Conditional touch reaction

ON TOUCH spriteA WITH spriteB
  TINT spriteA TO #ffff00
  IF spriteB.x IS 50
    LOG "Touched spriteB at x=50"
  END IF
END TOUCH
Tints spriteA on touch and logs an extra message if spriteB was at x=50 when touched.

In this tutorial, we will go over how to create a simple 'Catch The Guy' game where you must move around to touch the other person. If you would like to see how this game will look once you have finished the tutorial, you can view it
here.
Create a Project
We will start by creating a new project. We can do this by visiting
here.
On this page, you can create a new project. Give it a memorable nam  e and a description if you want!
Creating Sprites

For this game, we need 2 sprites. We can create a sprite by drawing in the Sprite editor and then saving it. This will give it a unique name such as 'sprite1' which you can use when coding. For our version of the game, we want 2 stick figure sprites. Be creative! But below is how ours will look in this tutorial.
https://i.imgur.com/De0sFqv.png
To make sure we don't lose our valuable art, we will save the game once we have created our Sprites. To do this, click the save button in the top action bar.
https://i.imgur.com/BeBILXD.png
Coding the Game

We can now start coding the game. We will start by spawning our sprites on other sides of the game canvas by using the SPAWN command. We will also set the text to some basic instructions so the player knows what to do, as well as storing the score.

STORE 0 AS score
TEXT 'You are the RED person. Use W/A/S/D to move around to touch the BLUE person to score!'
SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,50
SPAWN sprite2 AT 400,50
Next we are going to move our sprite that we control, using the ON KEY event as well as sprite variables.

STORE 0 AS score
TEXT 'You are the RED person. Use W/A/S/D to move around to touch the BLUE person to score!'
SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,50
SPAWN sprite2 AT 400,50

ON KEY 'w'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y-5
END KEY

ON KEY 's'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y+5
END KEY

ON KEY 'a'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x-5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON KEY 'd'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+5,sprite1.y
END KEY

You should then save your game again so we don't lose any progress. We can also test our game by playing it by clicking the play button in the game action bar. When you click this, in the popup once you click W/A/S/D you should see that the sprite moves.
https://i.imgur.com/qLgmtda.png
We are finally going to finish off our game by adding an ON TOUCH event so we can increase the score of the player when they do catch the blue guy.

STORE 0 AS score
TEXT 'You are the RED person. Use W/A/S/D to move around to touch the BLUE person to score!'
SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,50
SPAWN sprite2 AT 400,50

ON KEY 'w'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y-5
END KEY

ON KEY 's'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y+5
END KEY

ON KEY 'a'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x-5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON KEY 'd'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  STORE score+1 AS score
  TEXT "SCORE: ${score}"
  STORE 0#570 AS randomX
  STORE 0#350 AS randomY
  MOVE sprite2 TO randomX,randomY
END TOUCH
You can now save and play your game and you should see that we have a working version!
https://hc-cdn.hel1.your-objectstorage.com/s/v3/d71325966314ab5f3d4340c2a44522f6baed880f_chrome_29-september-2025_11-24.04.mp4
Extension: Rewarding XP
We can also make it so we can reward XP to the system wide level system when they do something. In this case, we will give them a SMALL package of XP whenever they touch someone.

STORE 0 AS score
TEXT 'You are the RED person. Use W/A/S/D to move around to touch the BLUE person to score!'
SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,50
SPAWN sprite2 AT 400,50

ON KEY 'w'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y-5
END KEY

ON KEY 's'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y+5
END KEY

ON KEY 'a'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x-5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON KEY 'd'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  GIVE XP SMALL
  STORE score+1 AS score
  TEXT "SCORE: ${score}"
  STORE 0#570 AS randomX
  STORE 0#350 AS randomY
  MOVE sprite2 TO randomX,randomY
END TOUCH
We can even add one time XP rewards when they hit a certain score. In this case, we will utilise the IF logic to give them a MEDIUM package of XP when they get a score of 5.

STORE 0 AS score
STORE 0 AS lastScore
TEXT 'You are the RED person. Use W/A/S/D to move around to touch the BLUE person to score!'
SPAWN sprite1 AT 0,50
SPAWN sprite2 AT 400,50

ON KEY 'w'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y-5
END KEY

ON KEY 's'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x,sprite1.y+5
END KEY

ON KEY 'a'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x-5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON KEY 'd'
  MOVE sprite1 TO sprite1.x+5,sprite1.y
END KEY

ON TOUCH sprite1 WITH sprite2
  GIVE XP SMALL
  STORE score+1 AS score
  STORE lastScore+1 AS lastScore
  TEXT "SCORE: ${score}"
  STORE 0#570 AS randomX
  STORE 0#350 AS randomY
  MOVE sprite2 TO randomX,randomY

  IF lastScore IS 5
    STORE 0 AS lastScore
    GIVE XP MEDIUM
  END IF

END TOUCH
